articles.headline: Easing Path Out of Country, Cuba Is Dropping Exit Visas
articles.snippet: The move by the government would allow many Cubans to depart for vacations, or forever, with only a passport and a visa from the country where they plan to go.
articles.abstract: The move by the government would allow many Cubans to depart for vacations, or forever, with only a passport and a visa from the country where they plan to go.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In a country of limits, it is the restriction that many Cubans hate the most: the exit visa that the government requires for travel abroad, discouraging all but the favored or fortunate from leaving the island.

articles.headline: Income Inequality May Take Toll on Growth
articles.snippet: The concentration of income in a few hands might mean, many economists say, a less vigorous economy.
articles.abstract: The concentration of income in a few hands might mean, many economists say, a less vigorous economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Income inequality has soared to the highest levels since the Great Depression, and the recession has done little to reverse the trend, with the top 1 percent of earners taking 93 percent of the income gains in the first full year of the recovery.

articles.headline: Economic Health? It’s Relative
articles.snippet: When compared with other nations involved in the financial decline four years ago, the United States has done well.
articles.abstract: When compared with other nations involved in the financial decline four years ago, the United States has done well.
articles.lead_paragraph: With financial markets careening around the world, in January 2009 a newly inaugurated President Obama acknowledged he had to fix the problem pretty fast. “If I don’t have this done in three years,” he told NBC’s Matt Lauer, “then there’s gonna be a one-term proposition.”

articles.headline: In Demanding Homes, Help in High Demand
articles.snippet: After a steep decline in the wake of the financial crisis, the domestic staffing business has come back, this time in a market that heavily favors the employers.
articles.abstract: After a steep decline in the wake of the financial crisis, the domestic staffing business has come back, this time in a market that heavily favors the employers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DELORES BETHELMIE seemed perfect to work as a nanny for the 1 percent.

articles.headline: Financial Survival in a Time of Fiscal Peril
articles.snippet: However Congress and the White House resolve the problem of the impending “fiscal cliff,” the months ahead are likely to be tumultuous. What should an investor do?
articles.abstract: However Congress and the White House resolve the problem of the impending “fiscal cliff,” the months ahead are likely to be tumultuous. What should an investor do?
articles.lead_paragraph: BETWEEN now and the end of the year, investors who are paying even the slightest bit of attention to the news will hear the term “fiscal cliff” repeated so often that it will surely either strike fear into their hearts or numb them to possible risks ahead.

articles.headline: N.Y.U. Law Plans Overhaul of Students’ Third Year
articles.snippet: Officials at New York University School of Law said they were trying to shift the curriculum to match what today’s legal profession demands.
articles.abstract: Officials at New York University School of Law said they were trying to shift the curriculum to match what today’s legal profession demands.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is an old saying that in the first year of law school they scare you to death; in the second year, they work you to death; and in the third year, they bore you to death.

articles.headline: Investors Hope for Clarity, Quickly
articles.snippet: Analysts see a need to jettison trailing businesses and get more out of the banking giant’s best performers.
articles.abstract: Analysts see a need to jettison trailing businesses and get more out of the banking giant’s best performers.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Michael L. Corbat takes up the reins at Citigroup, analysts and investors have a message for him: Shrink your bank fast, and be a lot more transparent as you do so.

articles.headline: In the Hard Fall of a Favorite Son, a Reminder of a City’s Scars
articles.snippet: Ike Maxwell walks the streets of Elyria, Ohio, as if determined to break through life’s defensive line. Often he is shouting. But what is he trying to say?
articles.abstract: Ike Maxwell walks the streets of Elyria, Ohio, as if determined to break through life’s defensive line. Often he is shouting. But what is he trying to say?

articles.headline: Maker of Batteries Files for Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The filing by A123 Systems dealt a blow to the Obama administration’s program to jump-start a domestic battery industry and spur development of electric vehicles.
articles.abstract: The filing by A123 Systems dealt a blow to the Obama administration’s program to jump-start a domestic battery industry and spur development of electric vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The troubled battery maker A123 Systems filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday, dealing a blow to the Obama administration’s program to jump-start a domestic battery industry and spur development of electric vehicles.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Rivals Bring Bare Fists to Rematch
articles.snippet: In a charged and clenched debate, President Obama portrayed Mitt Romney as a former corporate raider, while Mr. Romney kept bringing the discussion back to Mr. Obama’s record.
articles.abstract: In a charged and clenched debate, President Obama portrayed Mitt Romney as a former corporate raider, while Mr. Romney kept bringing the discussion back to Mr. Obama’s record.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama and Mitt Romney engaged Tuesday in one of the most intensive clashes in a televised presidential debate, with tensions between them spilling out in interruptions, personal rebukes and accusations of lying as they parried over the last four years under Mr. Obama and what the next four would look like under a President Romney.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: For the President, Punch, Punch, Another Punch
articles.snippet: President Obama emerged from the second debate with Mitt Romney having settled nerves within his party and claimed a new chance to frame the presidential race with just three weeks until Election Day.
articles.abstract: President Obama emerged from the second debate with Mitt Romney having settled nerves within his party and claimed a new chance to frame the presidential race with just three weeks until Election Day.
articles.lead_paragraph: He waited all of 45 seconds to make clear he came not just ready for a fight but ready to pick one.
